subTopics.title: Fundamental Rights - Split Panel View
subTopics.description: Navigate all major FR articles (Art 12-35) with master-detail interface showing organized content boxes for each article

keyTakeaways: Part III (Art 12-35) contains all Fundamental Rights
6 main categories: Equality, Freedom, Against Exploitation, Religion, Cultural-Educational, Constitutional Remedies
Art 14 (Equality) and Art 21 (Life & Liberty) most expansive and litigated
Art 19 originally had 7 freedoms; now 6 (property removed in 1978)
Art 32 (Constitutional Remedies) called 'heart and soul of Constitution' by Dr. Ambedkar
FRs not absolute - subject to reasonable restrictions
Art 13 makes FRs supreme over ordinary laws

topics.mainTopic: Directive Principles of State Policy (Part IV)
topics.description: Master all DPSPs (Articles 36-51) through Split-Panel interface with organized content boxes for each article

subTopics.title: DPSPs - Split Panel View
subTopics.description: Navigate all major DPSP articles (Art 36-51) with master-detail interface showing organized content for each directive principle

keyTakeaways: Part IV (Art 36-51) contains Directive Principles - non-justiciable but fundamental in governance
7 categories: Foundation, Social Justice, Economic, Gandhian, Administrative, Environmental, International
Art 37 declares DPSPs non-justiciable (unlike FRs) but fundamental
Art 39 has 6 crucial clauses (a-f) - frequently asked
Art 44 (UCC) most debated - only Goa has implemented
Art 48A (Environment) and Art 43A (Worker participation) added by 42nd Amendment 1976
DPSPs complement FRs: FRs are means, DPSPs are ends

studyTips: Use Split-Panel visual model to permanently retain concepts - master-detail interface allows quick navigation and deep content exploration
Article numbers are CRITICAL - Art 14, 19, 21, 32 for FRs; Art 37, 39, 44 for DPSPs
Understand FR vs DPSP distinction: FRs negative/justiciable/individual-centric vs DPSPs positive/non-justiciable/society-centric
Constitutional Amendments important: 1st (Art 15(4), 16(4)), 42nd (Art 48A, 43A), 44th (Property right removed), 86th (Art 21A education)
Landmark cases crucial: Maneka Gandhi (Art 21 expansion), Kesavananda Bharati (Basic Structure), Indra Sawhney (Reservation)
Art 19 originally 7 freedoms (a-g); Art 19(1)(f) property deleted by 44th Amendment 1978
Remember the 6 freedoms under Art 19: Speech, Assembly, Association, Movement, Residence, Profession
Art 21 most expansive - judicial creativity expanded to include privacy, livelihood, health, education, environment
Art 32 gives direct access to Supreme Court for FR violations - called 'heart of Constitution'
DPSPs implemented through laws: MGNREGA (Art 41), Maternity Act (Art 42), Minimum Wages (Art 43), 73rd Amendment (Art 40)
Gandhian DPSPs: Art 40 (Panchayats), Art 43 (Cottage industries), Art 47 (Prohibition), Art 48 (Cow protection)
Practice comparison questions: FR vs DPSP, different articles under same category

frequentTopics: Art 14: Equality before law - Rule of law, reasonable classification
Art 16: Equality in public employment - Reservation in jobs and promotions
Art 19: Six freedoms - Originally seven, property removed
Art 21: Life and personal liberty - Most expansive FR, includes right to privacy
Art 21A: Right to education - 86th Amendment, age 6-14
Art 32: Constitutional remedies - Five writs, 'heart of Constitution'
Art 14 vs Art 16: General equality vs Equality in employment
Art 19 vs Art 21: Specific freedoms vs Broad liberty
Art 25 vs Art 26: Individual religious freedom vs Institutional religious freedom
Art 29 vs Art 30: Minority cultural rights vs Educational institution rights
Art 37: DPSPs non-justiciable but fundamental in governance
Art 39: Six clauses (a-f) - Livelihood, common good, equal pay, etc.
Art 44: Uniform Civil Code - Only Goa implemented, Shah Bano case
FR vs DPSP: Justiciability, positive vs negative, individual vs society
Landmark cases: Maneka Gandhi, Kesavananda, Indra Sawhney, Minerva Mills
mustKnowDates: 2017 - Right to Privacy declared Fundamental Right (Puttaswamy case)
mustKnowCases: AK Gopalan (1950) - Narrow interpretation of Art 21; later overruled
Romesh Thappar (1950) - Freedom of press part of Art 19(1)(a)
Kesavananda Bharati (1973) - Basic Structure doctrine; Parliament cannot destroy Constitution's basic features
Maneka Gandhi (1978) - Revolutionary; Art 21 expanded; procedure must be fair, just, reasonable
Minerva Mills (1980) - Balance between FRs and DPSPs; neither absolute supremacy
MC Mehta cases (1980s-90s) - Environmental PIL; right to clean environment under Art 21
Indra Sawhney (1992) - OBC reservation valid; creamy layer concept; 50% ceiling
Mohini Jain (1992) - Right to education part of Art 21
TMA Pai (2002) - Minority institutions' rights under Art 30
KS Puttaswamy (2017) - Right to privacy part of Art 21; 9-judge bench
importantAspects: Article numbers with provisions - numerical accuracy crucial
Constitutional Amendments - know amendment number, year, and key changes
Landmark judgments - case name, year, key principle established
Comparison tables - FR vs DPSP, different articles, different categories
Visual models - Use Clock model for FRs, Staircase for DPSPs
Exceptions and limitations - When FRs can be restricted, DPSP implementation challenges
Mnemonic devices - Remember article groupings (12-13 Definition, 14-18 Equality, etc.)
Current affairs link - Recent judgments, new laws implementing DPSPs
Difference between similar articles - Art 14 vs 16, Art 25 vs 26, Art 29 vs 30
comparisonTables: Fundamental Rights vs Directive Principles (10+ points of distinction)
Art 25 (Individual Religious Freedom) vs Art 26 (Institutional Religious Freedom)
Art 29 (Cultural Rights) vs Art 30 (Educational Institution Rights)
Art 32 (SC for FR violations) vs Art 226 (HC for all rights)
Social Justice DPSPs vs Gandhian DPSPs vs Economic DPSPs
connections: Art 12 defines 'State' → All FRs enforceable against 'State' → Art 13 makes laws void if violating FRs
Art 14 Equality → Art 15 specific to social discrimination → Art 16 specific to employment
Art 19 specific freedoms → Art 21 broad liberty → Maneka Gandhi merged both (procedure for Art 19 must also be fair)
Art 21 Right to Life → Judicial expansion → Includes education → Led to Art 21A (86th Amendment)
Part III (FRs) → Individual rights → Part IV (DPSPs) → Social goals → Minerva Mills balanced both
Art 37 DPSPs non-justiciable → BUT courts use DPSPs to interpret FRs → Harmonious construction
Art 44 UCC directive → Shah Bano case → Political controversy → Muslim Women Act → UCC debate continues
Gandhian DPSPs (40, 43, 47, 48) → Rural focus → 73rd Amendment implemented Art 40 → Panchayati Raj
